A Discourse 
Of Mr Isaac Newton, containing 
his New Theory about light and 
Coulors, sent by him from Cambridge 
Febr. 6. 1671/72 to ye Secretary of ye 
R. Society, in order to be communica=
ted to that Body.
Sr 
To performe my late promise to you, I shall without further 
ceremony acquaint you, that in the begining of the yeare 1666
(at which time I applyed my selfe to the grinding of Opticke 
glasses of other figures then Sphericall) I procured me a Triangular 
glasse Prisme, to try wth the Celebrated Phaenemena of Colours 
And in order there to haue darkned my Chamber and made a 
small hole in my window=shuts to lett in a convenient quantity
of the Suns Light, I placed my Prisme at his entrance that it 
might be thereby refracted to the opposite wall. It was at first 
a very pleaseing divertisement to view the vivid and intense 
colours produced thereby, but after a while applying my selfe to 
consider them more circumspectly, I became Surprised to see them 
in an oblong forme wch according to the Received Laws of Refraction 
I expected should have been Circular 
They were terminated at the side with streight Lines, but at 
the ends, the decay of light was so gradual that it was difficult to 
determine justly, what was their figure, yet they seemed Semicir=
cular 
Compareing the length of this coloured Spectrum with its Breadth 
I found it aboue five tymes greater a disproportion soe extravagan[t]
that it excited me to a more then ordinary curiosity of examining
